All cmd commands are internal and throw Exceptions if they fail. The sendMail class is responsible for writing the error message to log. Only error codes are propgated further.
More authentication methods have to be implemented. These can be snatched from PEAR
Note: What about multiple sends with one connect only?
! Returns the receiver addresses as text with only the email address.
! Returns the receiver addresses as text.
! Returns the receiver cc addresses as an array with texts.
! Returns the receiver addresses as an array with texts.
! Returns the addresses which should get a carbon copy.
! Returns the addresses which should get a blind carbon copy.
! Returns the sender address as text.
! \return the MIME version for this email, normally this is 1.0. \note The value is returned as a string.
! \return the content type for this email, this is normally text/plain.
! \return the charset for this email, this is normally taken from the internal charset. \sa usedCharset
! \return the content transfer encoding, normally this is 8bit.
! \return the content disposition, normally this is inline.
! \return the user agent for this email, the user agent is automatically created if not specfied.
! Sets the various content variables, any parameter which is set to something other than \c false will overwrite the old value.
! Sets the user agent for the email to \a $agent.
! Sets the receiver address. \note This will remove all other receivers \sa addReceiver, setReceiverElements
! Sets the receiver address, the email and name will be extracted from \a $text. \note This will remove all other receivers \sa addReceiver, setReceiverElements
! Sets the sender address, the email and name will be extracted from \a $text.
! Adds the headers \a $headerName with header value \a $headerValue to the extra headers.
! Similar to addExtraHeader() but will overwrite existing entries.
! Returns the message ID format : <number@serverID> Read in the RFC's if you want to know more about it..
! Sets the message ID. This is a server setting only so BE CAREFUL WITH THIS.
! Returns the messageID that this message is a reply to.
! Sets the messageID that this message is a reply to.
! Sets the subject of the mail.
! \static Splits a list of email addresses into an array where each entry is an email address.
! \static Static function for validating e-mail addresses. Returns true if successful, false if not.
! \static Static function for extracting an e-mail from text Returns the first valid e-mail in address, returns false if no e-mail addresses found
! \static \returns a text which does not contain newlines, newlines are converted to spaces.
! \static \returns the header content as a simple string, will deflate arrays. \sa blankNewLines
! \static Composes a text out of the email and name and returns it. Example: John Doe <john@doe.com> or just john@doe.com
! \static Composes an email text out of all items in \a $items and returns it. All items are comma separated.

! \return an array with headers, each header item is an associative array with the keys \c name and \c content. \c content will either be a string or an array with strings. The parameter \a $parameters contains optional parameters, they can be: - exclude-headers - \c Array of header names which will not be included in the result array. \sa contentString, blankNewLines
! Extracts all headers and generates a text string out of it. The parameter \a $parameters will be passed to the headers() function.
! Composes a text field out of all the headers and returns it. The parameter \a $parameters will be passed to the headers() function.
! Calls convertText with \a $isHeader set to \c true.
! Converts the text \a $text to a suitable output format. \note Header conversion is not supported yet, for now it will only return original text when \a $isHeader is set to \c true.
! \return \c true if the charset \a $charset is allowed as output charset. \sa allowedCharsets.
! \return an array with charsets that can be used directly as output charsets.
! \return the charset which will be used for output.

! \class eZMailTransport ezmailtransport.php \brief Interface for mail transport handling
Function send is removed because it is application specific
! \virtual Tries to send the contents of the email object \a $mail and returns \c true if succesful.

Relevant documents: E-mail addresses: http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc822
Mime: http://www.sendmail.org/rfc/2045.txt and http://www.sendmail.org/rfc/2046.txt
setHeaders accept addresses in rfc822 format. All addresses are stored in this format internally. If you request the header you should get it back in rfc822 format. Maybe we need some conversion functions somewhere.
TODO: - Character sets. Should these be handled by the user / wrapper class or by mail itself? - Usage of Exceptions/Error codes. We need many more of both since the various functions may raise errors in both eZMailBody, eZMail and eZSMTPTransport - several more private functions are needed for eZMailBody and eZMail. This should be somewhat up to the implementor.

This class needs to be completely reviewed since the implementation is somewhat flaky. Simply make sure that it follows SMTP standards.
Removed: set - This should be replaced with properties if necessary

Constructor function. Arguments: $params - An assoc array of parameters: host - The hostname of the smtp server Default: localhost port - The port the smtp server runs on Default: 25 helo - What to send as the HELO command Default: localhost (typically the hostname of the machine this script runs on) auth - Whether to use basic authentication Default: FALSE user - Username for authentication Default: <blank> pass - Password for authentication Default: <blank> timeout - The timeout in seconds for the call Default: 5 to fsockopen()

Connect function. This will, when called statically, create a new smtp object, call the connect function (ie this function) and return it. When not called statically, it will connect to the server and send the HELO command.
Function to determine if this object is connected to the server or not.

Function which handles sending the mail. Arguments: $params - Optional assoc array of parameters. Can contain: recipients - Indexed array of recipients from - The from address. (used in MAIL FROM:), this will be the return path headers - Indexed array of headers, one header per array entry body - The body of the email It can also contain any of the parameters from the connect() function
Function that handles the MAIL FROM: cmd
Function that handles the RCPT TO: cmd
Function that sends the DATA cmd
Function to send a bit of data
